It was with reference to that company and the defence on the river below against the gunboats.
The 3d company of the battalion Capt. Miller, was on the 13th ordered to Chapin's Bluff, or some other convenient; point on the north bank of the river, to co-operate in the defence with the batteries on Drewry's Bluff.
On the evening of 14th, they were, by order of Gen. Lee, directed to report to Gen. Johnston.
This order was delivered by an artillery company from Montgomery, Alabama, which came to take its place, Capt. Miller then, on the night of the 14th, joined the battalion, and was not at the scene of the battle with the gunboats on the 15th.
The rumor, therefore, with reference to this company not firing, and the reason therefore, is without foundation.
Certainly the Washington Artillery has proved its high reputation sufficiently to discredit any rumor which might reflect upon it.

div3.head: An Omission.
div3.p:
In our notice of the recent fight at Drury's Bluff published in this paper a few days since, we unintentionally omitted to mention the participation of the companies of Captains J. D. Pearce and Wm. M. Patterson from Lynchburg and Campbell respectively These companies, together with those of Captains Sale, Bowyer, and Jones, owing to the urgency of the case, had been used as a fatigue party for several days previous to the fight; and on that memorable day were engaged in removing the obstructions caused by the caving in of the casemate over the best gun then in the battery.
They were exposed for nearly three hours to a most terrific storm of shot and shell, being within 350 yards of the enemy's gunboats, and at points black range.
As an evidence of the destructiveness of the enemy's fire it may be well to add, that all the casualties that occurred that day were at the point at which the above companies were employed.
Two men, M. Snead and Wm. L. Dodson, of Capt. Pierce's company, were slightly wounded, of Capt. Patterson, John Lewis was slightly wounded.

div3.head: William G. Brownlow.
div3.p:
Since the inauguration of the present struggle for Southern independence, Brownlow has been one of the most conspicuous character's of all the traitors who have taken sides against the South.
A Southerner by birth and residence, he has shown himself unworthy of the soil which has nurtured him, and side by side with that of Benedict Arnold will his name go down to posterity.
A Washington correspondent of the New York Times says that there is a general desire on the part of Unionists in Washington, that President Lincoln shall appoint William G. Brownlow a Brigadier General to lead a portion of their army into Knoxville.

Butler as Major General, and Brownlow as Brigadier!
What names to adorn the page of American history!
How resplendent will they appear alongside such illustrious charters as McClellan, Burnside, and Halleck!

div3.head: Burning the cotton.
div3.p:
--It is reported that the planters on the Mississippi, for twenty miles back from the river, have destroyed all their cotton, and that the planters on its tributaries, the Red, Arkansas, White, and St. Francis rivers, are following their patriotic example.
The occupation of the Father of Waters, therefore, will bring the enemy but little profit.
He has opened the greatest cotton port in the world, and yet he gets no cotton.
This is not all, the people in the great valley of the Mississippi have planted very little cotton — cut little more than enough for their own domestic purposes.

div3.head: Murders in New Orleans.
div3.p:
--In the New Orleans papers, of the 18th, we find accounts of fearful murders perpetrated by unknown ruffians upon Pedro Serrencull and his wife, who lived on their market garden opposite New Orleans.
They were stabbed to death in their own house, and their premises plundered of several hundred dollars. The papers dare not hint that the deed was done by Butler's scoundrels.

div3.head: Butler, the Knave.
div3.p:
--Among the first acts of Gen. Butler to preserve the police of the city of New Orleans, was to arrest May or Monroe and all the Aldermen, of whom the oath of allegiance to Lincoln was required.
They declining to take the oath, were committed to prison, and are now suffering for their patriotic firmness.
So we learn from an exchange.

div3.head: New map.
div3.p:
--Messrs. West & Johnston, of this city, have just published a large map of the State of Virginia, containing all the counties and principal towns, and showing the lines of railroad and other internal improvements.
It seems to have been prepared with great care, and will be found very useful for reference at the present time.

Mr. Evarts, of New York, at a New England society dinner described the three stages of the enterprising Yankee's progress; First, to get on; next, to get honor; and lastly, to get honest!--Boston True Flag.
It may be said of the above, that they generally succeed in the first, not often in the second, and never in the last.

div3.head: Salt.
div3.p: --The County Court of Pittsylvania last week appropriated $15,000 for the purchase of salt, to be distributed among the

div3.head:
The fight at Drury's Bluff.
Northern account.
a serious Defeat Admitted.
Bursting of a Parrot gun.
the Galena riddled by shot.
other boats Damaged.
from Norfolk and Portsmouth.
Trading Propensities of the Yankees, &c.
div3.p: --Late Northern papers received here contain some interesting news.

The repulse of the gunboats at Drury's Bluff had a most depressing effect in New York and Philadelphia.
It was regarded as a very serious affair at Old Point, but no full account was allowed to be made public Seventeen men were killed on the Saugatuck by the explosion of a hundred pound Parrot gun.--The boat was made useless and withdrawn from the fight.
The Gatena was riddled by shots from the rebel batteries Eighteen went through her decks and sides.
Fourteen of the crew were killed and thirteen wounded. The killed were terribly cut and mangled — many beyond the hope of recognition.

The Monitor maintained its reputation for superior strength and invulnerability.
The balls glanced harmless from her prow.
The Aristock and Port Royal were not materially injured.
The unusual elevation of the rebel battery and the difficulty of gunboats getting the proper range, the latter were for a time unable to do execution.
In the meantime the rebel battery poured an incessant fire of shot and shell upon the decks of the gunboats, and did a fearful work.
The body of M. Boernan, gunner of the Galena, was carried to Fortress Monroe for interment.

Seward and Welles visited Norfolk on Friday.
Col. Brown, of the 20th Indiana regiment, stationed at Portsmouth, went out of town to take a ride.
An hour afterwards his horse returned wounded and riderless.
He is supported to have been killed by rebels.
Nothing important in the papers from Halleck or McClellan, and not a word about Milroy or Cox.

Over five hundred vessels are advertised to sail for Southern ports by the first of June.
It is said there will be two hundred clearances for cargoes of ice.

div3.head: Attention, Wise Mounted Guard.
div3.p: --Every member of this company will report themselves at Camp Howard's Grove this morning, at 9 o'clock A. M. All failing to do so will be treated as deserters.
An election for Junior Lieutenant will take place at 10 o'clock A. M.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley, Captain,
my 24--1t* Wise Mounted Guard.

div3.head:
Headq'rs 4th Va Cavalry.
near Meadow's Bridge, May 21, 1862.
div3.p:
A Number of men belonging to this Regiment are absent without leave.
If they do not join the Regiment at once, their names, and the circumstances under which they left, will be published.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. B. H. Robertson.
Walter K. Martin, Adjutant
my 24--3t

div3.head: Gwathmey House Hospital, Richmond, May 23, 1862.
div3.p: to out-patients of the Gwathmey House Hospital (lately known as the Maryland Hospital). --All out-patients of the Gwathmey House Hospital will report either in person, or by their medical attendant, civil or military, within twenty-four hours, or be reported as deserters.
div3.closer:
G. Wm. Semple, Surgeon C. S. A.
In charge Gwathmey House Hospital.
my 24--1t*

div3.head: Bayed Island Hospital, Richmond, May 24, 1862.
div3.p: Notice.--All sick soldiers who have registered their names at this Hospital and reside in private houses in or near the city, are required to reported in person, or through their medical advisers, at this Hospital within twenty-four hours, failing to do which they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order Surgeon-General S. P. Moore,
Alex. Y. P. Garnett.
my 24--1t* Surgeon in charge.

div3.head: Globe Hospital,Richmond May 23d, 1862.
div3.p:
all patients registered in this Hospital and allowed to go to "private quarters" are hereby ordered to report immediately, either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine, military or civil.
Falling to do so they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of the Surgeon-General', C. S. A.
St George Peachy, P. A. C. S.

div3.head: Medical College Hospital, Richmond, May 23, 1862.
div3.p: in pursuance of orders received from the Surgeon General, all sick soldiers who have been transferred from this hospital to private houses are hereby required to report within twenty- four hours either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine military or civil, failing to do which, they will be advertised as deserters.

my 24--1t President.

div3.head: Louisiana Hospital, Richmond, May 28, 1862.
div3.p:
out-patients of this Hospital are required to report at this Hospital within 24 hours, either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine, military or civil.
Failing in this, they will be advertised as deserters.

div3.p:
--All out-patients registered in the Banner Hospital, will report within 24 hours, either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine, military or civil.
Failing to do which, they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:

div3.head: Chimborazo Hospital.
div3.p: Out-Patients must report in person, or by their attending physician or surgeon, at the Central Office of this Hospital, this Afternoon, between the hours of 4 and 6, or be published as deserters.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 124, page 4.

div3.head: A French View of Mexico.
div3.p:
Under the heading of "The truth about Mexico," a late number of the Courier des Etate Unis says that nothing is more common than to talk about the situation of Mexico, but nothing is more rare than to discuss the subject with reasonable knowledge of the facts.--People are accustomed to consider not so much the Government of Juarez as the word that serves him for a battle cry; and because the President of Mexico and his satellites call themselves Liberals, people willingly believe that liberalism is at stake in the dispute that is a son to be decided in Mexico.
Thinking it time that such an error should cease, and that the factiousness who have too long desolated the Spanish Republic should be restored to their true colors, without regard to the name which they have seen fit to appropriate, the editor of the Courier copies an ably written letter from Vera Cruz to the Paris Journal des Debate, setting forth "the real situation of Mexico, exposing the contemptible adventurers who fatten off of her, and stating the legitimate aspirations of the mass of the population."

The writer of this letter says that there is neither Liberal, nor clerical or reactionary party in Mexico.
There are simply audacious robbers, without scrapples of any kind on the one hand, and victims well-used to the yoke and pretty nearly resigned to their wretched fate on the other hand.
The population of Mexico is not 8,000,000 as is generally believed, but only six millions, composed of 5,400,000 pure or half-breed Indians and 600,000 white men whose blood is more or less mixed with Indians and negroes.
The Indians are so sunk in ignorance that in some parts they believe themselves to be still subject to Spain.
A few thousand of them drawn away from their labors by the civil wars take an active part in the disastrous struggles which are waged for the benefit of five or six knaves, half of whom call themselves Liberals, and the other half Reactionists.
All the rest of the population, the real people, desire only to work and live in peace in this country, which would be great in a few years under a true Government; for poverty is rare, and it would be altogether unknown if there was only a better security for person and property.

The two parties divide the six hundred thousand Mexicans, properly so called, pretty equally, the greater part of them affecting political passions far enough from their real sentiments.
This is easily enough understood when it is taken into consideration that to belong to the defeated party is to furnish a warrant of spoliation, which the poor victim rarely escapes, often even suffering death; and one runs the same risks in his own party, if he should be suspected of any moderation.

To sympathize with Juarez and his Government because they chose to call themselves Liberals, would be in reality to approve of a state of siege, robbery, murder, the absence of all guaranty, of all liberty, and all honesty.
These people steal from Governments as well as from individuals, as witness the $40,000 belonging to France stolen by the Juarez Government from the bank of M. Penand, where the money was deposited, and the $630,000 stolen by Miramon from the English Legation.
There is some difference in the amounts stolen, it is true, but the only difference between the thieves is the regret on the part of Juarez that he could not steal as much as his antagonist.
The choice made by Juarez of his Executive officers shows well enough what he is. Porfi Leon, the Chief of Police in Mexico, is a notorious robber, and served seven years in the chain gang for assassination--three of them in the city of Mexico itself.--He was the plotter of the recent attempt on the life of the French Minister, Salighy, and, by way of satisfying the complaints of the French Government, he has been promoted to be Brigadier-General.
Carvajal, Ceellard, Rojas, and the greater part of the other Generals now actively employed by Juarez, were mere brigands, and were commissioned Generals when they brought their cut-throats to take service with his party.

The only thing organized in Mexico is highway robbery.
At every station between Vera Cruz and Mexico a sum of money is taken from travellers for the benefit of the robbers.
It is like a regular tax, added to the price of passage.
Women sometimes have to pay more than money.

Marquez arrives at a town and demands $10,000 for the defenders of religion.
If the money cannot be supplied, he shoots twenty-five persons, under pretence that if they have no money it must be because they have given it to his enemies.
In eight days afterwards, Carvajal will come to the same town, and twenty-five more wretches are shot under a similar pretence.
In one district alone, about the size of a French Department, fifteen hundred persons have perished in this manner.
The correspondent of the Journal des Debats concludes his graphic letter by repeating that there are no such things as political parties in Mexico.
There are oppressors and there are opposed.
So far as the latter are concerned, the only difference between the former is, that one eats them with red sauce, and the other with black; and as the alternative is constantly presented anew, those who escape the one are pretty sure to fail victims to the other.
The only remedy for this terrible state of things, says the French writer, is a strong Government, under which "the good shall be reassured, and the wicked shall tremble."

div3.head: Maryland Partisan corps.
div3.p: The attention of Maryland and District men is called to this service, to which they are so particularly adapted, and which will give them the best opportunity to avenge the insults offered to our glorious old State.
Already three entire companies of the 1st Maryland regiment have joined, and a majority from several of the other companies have requested to be transferred.
This corps will be independent of all other commands, save that of the General commanding the Department of Virginia, and will act as nearly as possible on the frontiers of Maryland.

As the Conscription act does not apply to Marylanders, they occupy the same position as though it bad never been passed, and hence all 12 months men can claim transfer to this corps, if re- enlisted; or, if not re-enlisted, can be discharged upon or after the expiration of their term of service.
Horses will be furnished those who desire to join the Cavalry and are unable to provide their own.
In addition to the pay, rations, and bounty, (which are the same as in regular service,) the value of all captures from the enemy will be distributed among the men.
The corps will be composed of Cavalry, Artillery, and Infantry, and commanded by a distinguished officer of the army.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining the command will apply to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 14--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head:
Henrico Artillery.
Ritter's Battery.
div3.p: All men absent from this company without leave are hereby ordered to report themselves forthwith for duty, at the camp at Fairfield Race Course, or they will be advertised and treated as deserters.
The following parties are deserters — for whose apprehension and delivery to any officer a liberal reward will be paid:
Meghan and Maloney took away horses belonging to the battery.
div3.closer:
W. B. Ritter, Captain
my 23--3t* Com'g Company.

div3.head: Attention ! Marylanders.
div3.p: The undersigned is authorized by the Secretary of War to enlist a Partisan company of Marylanders, to be attached to the Maryland Line, under the orders of Brigadier-General Stenart; to be enlisted for the war, and to receive the same bounty, ($50,) pay, &c., as other volunteers.
Horses will be furnished by private contribution to those who are unable to procure them, and the Government will furnish arms and equipments where needed.

Native or adopted citizens of Maryland now in the service, in any regiment other than the 1st Maryland regiment, who wish to join this arm of service, can be transferred under General Order No. 8, Special Order No. 107, by application to Major Geo H. Kyle, or to
div3.closer:
G. M. Emack,
Lt. C. S. A. and Recruiting Officer,
my 23--1w* No. 14 Pearl st., Richmond.

div3.head: Partisan Troop for Kentucky and Tennessee !
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise a Partisan Troop for operations in Kentucky and Tennessee.
Those who wish to join in this "dashing," "dare-devil" business, and serve their country like good and true men, can do so by applying to me. --There will be $50 county granted by the Government, and the troop will be well mounted and thoroughly equipped ! None but sound, good, dashing fellows need apply; for, as the service will be chivalrous, adventurous, and dangerous, none but unexceptionable young men will be received.
Those who wish to emulate Morgan and his troop have now an opportunity by applying to
div3.closer:
Capt Wm. H. Rowan,
No. 12, Columbian Hotel, 13th street.
my 23--6t*

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p:
In consequence of not being able to purchase horses in Richmond, I have deemed it best to make Lynchburg the point of rendezvous for my company of Partisan Rangers.
Additional members will be received.
The attention of those desiring to join my company is called to the fact that they will be furnished with horses and equipments, and the usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
My office, on Bank, near 10th street, will be kept open, where transportation to place of rendezvous can be had. I am anxious to go into service at an early day; hence, those who feel disposed to join my company will please report at once.
div3.closer: my 23--6t* L. R. Smoot.

div3.head:
Hd'qrs Mounted Riflemen,
Scott's Partisan Rangers,
Opp.
Spotswood Hotel.
div3.p:
Every member of this company is ordered to report to me, at the Recruiting Office, by 9 o'clock, at which time he will be mustered in with the company, draw his bounty, and receive his commutation for clothing.
Every one who has signed the muster-roll failing to report will be reported to the Provost Marshal, and arrested wherever found.
div3.closer:
Edw'd McCONNELL. Jr.,
Capt. Mounted Riflemen,
my 23--2t* and Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: Home duty.
div3.p:
--The undersigned, by authority of the Secretary of War, is raising a company for Garrison, Guard, and Prison duty.
All good men, between 35 and 45 years, persons not already in the service, and those who have been discharged, will be received.
The usual clothing and bounty money given, with subsistence until the company is organized.
Apply at Gen. Winder's office.
div3.closer:
Warner Lewis,
A. D. C. to Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder.
my 22--3t*

div3.head: Maryland Line.
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise an Infantry company for the Maryland Line.
Citizens of Maryland desiring to unite themselves with the line, are invited to join me.--The company will elect its own officers.
I can be found for the present at the Pay Office of the Confederate Forces, corner of Bank and 10th streets. Bounty and transportation furnished without delay.
div3.closer:
Campbell W. Pinckney,
my 22--t31stM* Of Maryland.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p: --From my company, at Camp Winder, the following men, for which I will pay the reward of thirty dollars each, if delivered at the Provost Marshal's office:

Julius Lang, aged 20 years, gray eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, about 5 feet 7 inches high.
Born in Hansen, Germany, and by profession a shoemaker.

Julius T. Polk, aged 29 years, brown eyes, auburn hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 11 inches high.
Born in Southampton, Virginia, and by profession a printer; he is well known in this city.

Frederick Brune, aged 30 years, brown eyes, auburn hair, light complexion, 5 feet 8 inches high.
Born in Wirtenberg, Germany, and by profession a ship carpenter.
It is supposed that he has enlisted in some cavalry company near the city.

John Smith, aged 23 years, gray eyes, auburn hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 8 inches high.
Born in Liverpool, England, and by profession a laborer; has lost his left eye.
All members in the city and absent without leave will immediately report at camp, or be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
John Herbig,
Captain of Infirmary Company,
Camp Winder, May 20, 1862. my 21--4t*

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.
div3.p:
--Authorized by the Secretary of War.
According to the recent act of Congress, creating a "Partisan Corps," to muster into service a squadron of two or more companies of Mounted Rangers for immediate action, I call upon my friends from the country lying between the "Blue Ridge" and the "Occoquan," to unite with me in this favored corps; as by previous experience as a Cavalry officer, engaged for twelve months in similar service, with a knowledge of the field of operations.
I believe we may contribute much to the benefit of our cause.
Communications may be addressed me at Gordonsville, Oranges county, Va. Recruits will be provided for at that Station.
div3.closer:
Bounty, $50. Pay, &c., as Cavalry.
Ed. B. Powell,
Late Captain Co. F, 6th Va. Cavalry.
my 21--6t*

div3.head:
Headquarters Co. F, 23d Va. Vols,
army of the valley.
div3.p:
Deserters.--Private John T. Warrener, of Company F, after receiving his bounty and furlough, has never returned.
Said Warrener is about 21 years of age; medium size; red, bluffy face; curly hair, and altogether has a bad countenance.
Up to the time of re-enlistment, he had been of very little service to his company.
He is supposed to be lurking in the neighborhood of Rocketts.

On the 5th of May, private S. P. Johnson, aged 33 years. He, by his previous course of conduct, seems entirely indisposed to serve his country.
Whatever is due the above-named men will be paid for their delivery at camp.
Other members of this corps absent on sick furloughs, will report immediately at headquarters. --If unable by sickness, they will send a Surgeon's certificate to that effect.
div3.closer: my 20--14t* T. S. Michaels, Captain.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Crisiding.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
mh 28--ts Captain Light Artillery.

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p:
--Persons belonging to the 8th and 14th Alabama, and the 14th Louisiana regiments--Pryor's Brigade — will report at once to their respective Regimental Headquarters.
Otherwise they will be published and prosecuted as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. Payor:
my 19--7t* Jno. E. Jones, A. D. C.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adjutant Generals Office,
Richmond, Va., May 17, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 36.
list.item: I. All applications for discharge, made by persons ever 35 years of age, who may have been drafted since 10th March, 1862, under the Virginia laws, and assigned to military organizations serving under authority of the Confederate States, will be granted by Brigade commanders; regimental and company commanders causing to be made out and signing the "Soldier's Discharge" and "Final Statements" required in all cases of discharge, said papers to indicate cause for the discharge.

II.
In all cases where promotion is due from seniority and the competency of the parties entitled by position to promotion is questionable, a Board of Exam shall be convened by Brigade Commanders to determine the candidates' capabilities of instructing and controlling the commands commensurate with grade to which promotion is expected, as also their efficiency and perfect

div3.closer:
By order of the Secretary of War
(Signed) S. Cooper,
my 12--1w Adj't and Inspector General.

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.--
div3.p:
My Battalion of Mounted Rangers will be ready to take the field in two weeks. Only one more company required.
Those withing to unite will please address me immediately.
div3.closer:
Lt. Col. W. C. Claiborne,
my 10--ts Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Exemption.
div3.p: The following General Order is published by authority of the Secretary of War:
War Department, Adj't and Insp'r Gen.'s Office, Richmond, May 19, 1862.
General Orders, No. 37.
I. The following act and regulations in reference thereto, are published for the information of all concerned:
an act to exempt certain persons from enrollment for service in the armies of the Confederate States.

Section 1. The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact.
That all persons who shall be held to be unfit for military service under rules to be prescribed by the Secretary of War--all in the service on employ of the Confederate States--all judicial and executive officers of the Confederate or State Governments — the members of both Houses of Congress and the Legislatures of the several States and their respective officers — all clerks of the officers of the State and Confederate Governments allowed by law — all engaged in carrying the mails — all ferrymen on post routes — all pilots and persons engaged in the marine service on river and railroad routes of transportation — telegraphic operators and ministers of religion in the regular discharge of ministerial duties — all engaged in working iron mines, furnaces, and foundries — all journeymen printers actually employed in printing newspapers — all presidents and professors of colleges and academies, and all teachers having as many as twenty scholars — superintendents of the public hospitals, lunatic asylums, and the regular nurses and attendants therein, and the teachers employed in the institutions for the deaf and dumb and blind — in each apothecary store now established and doing business, one apothecary in good standing, who is a practical druggist — superintendents and operatives in wool and cotton factories who may be exempted by the Secretary of War, shall be, and are hereby, exempted from military service in the armies of the Confederate States.
Approved April 21, 1862.

II.
By the above act of Congress, the following classes of persons are exempt from enrollment for military service:

Justices of the Peace; Sheriffs and Deputy Sheriffs; Clerks and Deputy Clerks, allowed by law; Masters and Commissioners in Chancery; District and State Attorneys; Attorney General; Postmasters and Deputy Postmasters, and Clerks allowed by law; Commissioners of Revenue, and foreigners who have not acquired domicil in the Confederate States.

III.
The following are not exempt:
Militia Officers not in actual service; persons exempt by State laws, but not by the above act; foreigners who have acquired domicil in the Confederate States.

IV.
No persons other than those expressly named or properly implied in the above act can be exempted, except by furnishing a substitute, exempt from military service, in conformity with regulations already published, (General Orders No. 29;) and such exemption is valid only so long as the said substitute is legally exempt.

V. Persons who have furnished substitutes will receive their certificates of exemption from the Captains of companies, or the Commandants of camps, by whom the substitutes have been accepted.
Other certificates of exemption will be granted by the enrolling officers only, who will receive full instructions in regard to the conditions and mode of exemptions.
Applications for exemption cannot, therefore, be considered by the War Department.
By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
Adj't and Insp'r Gen'l.
The following are the regulations concerning substitutes, above referred to:

list.head: General Orders, no. 29.
list.item:
I. The following regulations concerning substitutes in the army are published by the direction of the Secretary of War:
1.
Any non-commissioned officer or soldier not indebted to the Government, who wishes to procure a substitute, may obtain from his captain a permit for the proposed substitute to report himself at the camp or the company for examination; and such permit shall operate as a passport, but shall not entitle the holder to transportation at the expense of the Government.
2. If the substitute be exempt from military duty, and, on examination by a surgeon or assistant surgeon of the army, be pronounced sound and in all respects fit for military service, he shall be enrolled and mustered into service for three years, unless the war sooner terminate; and the non-commissioned officer or soldier procuring him shall thereupon be discharged, but shall not be entitled to transportation at the expense of the Government.
3. If a non-commissioned officer or soldier discharged by reason of a substitute be indebted to the Government, the officer granting the discharge shall be liable for the debt.
4. All pay and allowance due to the non-commissioned officer or soldier discharged shall go to the substitute at the next pay day. 5.
Substitution shall not exceed one per month in each company, and shall be noted in the next morning report, muster roll, and monthly return.

II.
When any person liable to military duty under the act of Congress, but not mustered into service in any company, desires to furnish a substitute, he shall report himself, with the substitute, to the commandant of a camp of instruction, for recruits raised under the said act; and if the substitute be lawfully exempt from military duty, and, on examination by a surgeon or assistant surgeon, be pronounced sound, and in all respects fit for military service, he may be accepted and enrolled, and the person furnishing such a substitute may be discharged by the commandant of the camp.
But no substitute shall be entitled to transportation or other allowance at the expense of the Government until so accepted and enrolled.
my 20--d1w

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, May 15th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No.--
I. At a General Court-Martial assembled at Richmond, Va., pursuant to Paragraph 11, Special Orders No. 57, Headquarters Department Henrico, April 2d, 1864, were arraigned and tried--

2d Captain Wm. F. McLean, of Company (A) 59th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, formerly known as the Ben McCulloch Rangers 2d Regiment Infantry, Wise Legion, upon the following charges and specifications: (The specifications being so various and detailed are omitted in this order.)

div4.head: Charge First.
div4.p: Exciting mutiny in a company in the service of the Confederate States, in violation of the 7th Article of War.

div4.head: Charge second.
div4.p: Fraudulent conversion to his own use of property belonging to others; which came into his possession by virtue of his office as Captain.

div4.head: Charge third.
div4.p: Allowing members of his company to leave the service without a proper discharge.
To which charges and specifications the accused pleaded Not Guilty, and the Court having maturely considered the evidence adduced, find the said Captain William F. McLean, as follows:

q.p: "On the first specification of the first charge, Guilty, except the words, 'addressed to him as Captain of said Company;' On the second specification of first charge, Guilty; On the first specification of first charge, Not Guilty, On the fourth specification of first charge, Guilty, On the first charge, Guilty, On the first specification of second charge, Guilty, On the second specification of second charge, Not Guilty, On the third specification of second charge, Guilty, On the fourth specification of second charge, Not Guilty, On the second charge, Guilty, On the specification of third charge, Not Guilty, On the third charge, Not Guilty,"

div4.p: And the Court therefore sentences the said Captain Wm. F. McLean "to be cashiered, and do order that his offence, name, place of abode, and punishment, be published in the news papers of Richmond, Va., and New Orleans, La."

II.
The proceedings, findings, and sentence of the Court in the foregoing case are hereby approved; and the said Captain Wm. F. McLean, of New Orleans La., ceases from this date to be an officer of the Confederate States Army.
div4.closer:
By order of
Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder,
Commending, &c.
L. H. Page, A. A. General.
my 20--6t

div3.head: Maryland Partisan corps.
div3.p: --It is proposed to organize a Partisan corps of Maryland men, to act as nearly as possible on the frontier of our own State.
The corps to consist of Cavalry, Artillery and infantry, and to be under command of Colonel Walter H. Jeniter, who has accepted the raise.
Horace will be furnished to those who desire to join the cavalry, if unable to provide their own.

The Secretary of War having decided that Marylanders are exempt from the provisions of the Conscriptions act, all twelve months men from that State can claim transfer to this corps at or after the expiration of their term of service.
Pay, rations and bounty same as in regular service.
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 10--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All members of the Allen Artillery absent with or without leave, will report immediately at Battery No. 3, or they will be published as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of T. P. Wilkinson, Captain Commanding Allen Artillery.
my 20--st* Geo W. Boss, O. S.

div3.head: Attention, Martin's Battery!
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once at "Camp Lee," or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the Recruiting officer, corner of Bank and 12th streets.
div3.closer:
S. Taylor Martin, Captain.
ap 31--ts.
